title: Spotify has reached 100m paying subscribers in Europe, Daniel Ek confirms
description: Spotify reported on April 29 that it grew its global Premium Subscriber base to 268m paying users in Q1 Source
author: Murray Stassen

html:
Spotify has officially reached 100 million paying subscribers in Europe.

Thatâ€™s according to a LinkedIn post from co-founder and CEO Daniel Ek, who said he shared news of the milestone at an event in Stockholm this week.

Spotify reported on April 29 that it grew its global Premium Subscriber base to 268 million paying users in Q1 (the three months ended March 31).

That was up 12%Â YoY, and up byÂ 5Â millionÂ net subscribers on theÂ 263Â millionÂ that SPOT counted at the end of the prior quarter (Q4 2024).

The company projected that its total Premium Subscriber base will hit 273Â million in Q2 of this year (the three months ended June 30), an addition of approximatelyÂ 5 millionÂ net new subscribers in the quarter.

Ek said in his social media post today (May 27) that Europe is now home to nearly â€œ40% of [Spotifyâ€™s] global premium subscriber baseâ€.

Spotifyâ€™s most recent earnings presentation (for Q1, 2025) included a chart confirming that Europe accounted for 37% (or 99.16m) of its total subscriber base in Q1.

Latin America and â€˜Rest of Worldâ€™ accounted for 23% and 14%, respectively.

North America, meanwhile, accounted for 26%, which suggests that the platform counted 69.68 million Premium Subscribers in North America as of Q1 2025.

Spotifyâ€™s earnings report didnâ€™t break out the percentage for the US and Canada individually.

Spotify recently said that its US iOS app update, approved by Apple earlier this month, drove â€œa significant increaseâ€ in conversions from free to Premium subscriptions in the market.

Sharing the news on LinkedIn today (May 27), Daniel Ek said: â€œOnce a year, we open the doors to our Stockholm HQ to welcome guests from across Europe. This year, I had the chance to take everyone through Spotifyâ€™s founding journey, a story Iâ€™ve told many times, but one that still feels special.

â€œWhat made this time different was that I also got to share a huge milestone: Spotify has now reached 100 million paying subscribers in Europe.â€

â€œWhen we launched in 2008, we did so market by market, trying to explain to our partners what streaming could become. Back then, just getting to one million paying users in Europe in 2011 felt like a huge win.â€

Daniel Ek

Ek added: â€œWhen we launched in 2008, we did so market by market, trying to explain to our partners what streaming could become. Back then, just getting to one million paying users in Europe in 2011 felt like a huge win. Fast forward to today, and Europe is home to nearly 40% of our global Premium subscriber base.

â€œThe growth is incredible, but what matters even more is the connection weâ€™ve built along the way. With our users, whoâ€™ve made Spotify part of their daily lives, and the connections thatâ€™s made between fans, artists, authors and creators, every single day. Iâ€™m super proud of what weâ€™ve built and so excited about whatâ€™s next. ğŸ™â€

In Europe, Spotify recently implemented price increases for subscribers across Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg.

This marks the second major price adjustment for Spotify in the Benelux region since July 2023 when the companyÂ rolled outÂ price increases across North America, Europe, and Asia.

In theÂ NetherlandsÂ andÂ Luxembourg, an individual subscription now costsÂ â‚¬12.99Â (USD $14.81 at the current exchange rate), upÂ 18%Â from â‚¬10.99.

The price increase in the Benelux region now exceeds the prices of Spotifyâ€™s services in larger neighboring economies. In comparison, individual plans inÂ GermanyÂ andÂ SpainÂ remain atÂ â‚¬10.99, while French subscribers payÂ â‚¬11.12Â ($12.66).Â Switzerland, meanwhile, is priced higher atÂ 13.95 CHFÂ ($17.04) for an individual subscription.

Â Music Business Worldwide
